questions.text: A patient was put on morphine for cancer pain due to carcinoma of the pancreas. His pain got relieved initially, but now, after 3 weeks, the pain is not get relieved. The reason is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Desensitization of opioid receptors Chronic use of opioids leads to the development of tolerance. To get the same effect, we need to use a high drug dose. This is due to the desensitization of opioid receptors Tolerance develops to all the effects of morphine except Miosis, Constipation, and Convulsions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Decreased absorption of morphine is a wrong statement Option: B . Opioid receptors get downregulated over the period Option: D. Increased elimination of morphine is a wrong statement.

questions.text: Placebo works by releasing endorphins, which are endogenous opioids. These endorphins mainly act at:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mu receptor The mu receptors are a class of receptors that neuromodulate different physiological functions, but above all, nociception but also stress, temperature, respiration, endocrine activity, gastrointestinal activity, memory, mood, and motivation because these receptors bind opioids and are called mu-opioid receptors (MORs).

Highyeild:

Endogenous Opioids Are Endorphins Enkephalin Dynorphins Nociceptin Opioid receptors Affinity of endogenous opioids Mu Endomorphins-endorphin> Enkephalins-dynorphins Delta enkephalin -endorphin> dynorphins Kappa Dynorphin = endorphin>Enkephalins N/OFQ Nociceptin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Delta receptor- The ∆-opioid receptor, also known as delta opioid receptor or simply delta receptor, abbreviated DOR or DOP, is an inhibitory 7-transmembrane G-protein coupled receptor coupled to the G protein Gi/G0 and has enkephalins as its endogenous ligands. Optio n: C. Kappa receptor The κ-opioid receptor or kappa opioid receptor, abbreviated KOR or KOP for its ligand ketazocine, is a G protein-coupled receptor that in humans is encoded by the OPRK1 gene. Option: D. The N/OFQ is well accepted as a core component of the brain’s anti-stress system by counteracting the endogenous corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF) action. Emerging evidence shows that the N/OFQ-NOP receptor system regulates stress and addiction-related behavior.

questions.text: Morphine is an opioid analgesic used to relieve visceral pain and cancer pain. In which of the following morphine should not be given in?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biliary colic

Highyeild:

Morphine Relaxes longitudinal smooth muscles and constricts circular muscles like in sphincters So it causes constipation and miosis. But in gall bladder, it constricts the sphincter of odd and increases biliary pressure, so not used in biliary colic. Atropine can treat this, but pure opioid antagonists are used to prevent morphine-induced biliary spasms. Morphine is used in other conditions mentioned in options, like ischemic pain (like mi), cancer pain, and postoperative pain.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Ischemic pain is classically associated with an insidious onset but can present in the acute or chronic setting. Treatments are aimed at improving perfusion to the affected tissue. Surgical options include repairing damaged vessels, bypassing diseased vessels, and performing thrombectomy or embolectom Option: B . Cancer pain: Pain in cancer may arise from a tumor compressing or infiltrating nearby body parts; from treatments and diagnostic procedures; or from skin, nerve, and other changes caused by a hormone imbalance or immune response. Option: D. Postoperative pain: Postoperative pain control aims to reduce the negative consequences associated with acute postsurgical pain and help the patient transition back to normal function. Traditionally, opioid analgesic therapy has served as the mainstay of treatment for acute postoperative pain.

questions.text: An Intern gave a trauma patient with a head injury morphine to relieve a headache. But the senior resident told to intern that he shouldn’t have administered it. The reason is?

options.label: B
options.text: Opioids also can cause marked respiratory depression

options.label: C
options.text: Morphine interferes with the assessment of progress in head injury cases

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above As opioids induce retention of CO2, it increases intracranial tension, worsening the head injury. Therapeutic doses of opioids also can cause marked respiratory depression in these patients. Clinical manifestations like vomiting, miosis, and altered sensorium produced by morphine interfere with assessing progress in head injury cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Opioids induce retention of CO2 Option: B. Opioids also can cause marked respiratory depression Option: C. Morphine interferes with the assessment of progress in head injury cases

questions.text: An opioid addict overdosed on morphine through an IV route and was rushed to the emergency room. He had flaccidity, shallow and occasional breathing, cyanosis, pinpoint pupil, and a fall in BP. Which of the following is incorrect about acute morphine poisoning management?

options.label: B
options.text: No need to do gastric lavage when morphine is taken IV

options.label: C
options.text: Poisoning may occur accidentally or suicide or in drug abusers

options.label: D
options.text: Death is due to respiratory failure.

questions.correct_answer: B. No need to do gastric lavage when morphine is taken IV
questions.explanation:
Solution:

No need to do gastric lavage when morphine is taken IV REASON- Gastric lavage with KMnO4 even if morphine is taken IV Options A, C, D-

Highyeild:

Acute morphine poisoning Can occur accidentally or suicide or in drug abusers 50 mg of morphine i.m. produces serious toxicity in intolerant individuals The human lethal dose is estimated to be about 250 mg. Features of morphine poisoning include Stupor or coma, flaccidity, shallow and occasional breathing Cyanosis, pinpoint pupil Fall in BP and shock, convulsions Pulmonary edema Death is due to respiratory failure. Treatment: Supportive Gastric lavage with KMnO4, even if morphine is taken IV Lavage is indicated even when morphine has been injected. Being a primary drug, it is partitioned to the acid gastric juice, ionizes there, and does not diffuse back into the blood The specific antidote is Naloxone 0.4–0.8 mg i.v. Repeated every 2–3 min till respiration picks up Doesn’t depress respiration Depending on the response dose is repeated every 1–4 hours

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Naloxone is the DOC Option: C. Poisoning may occur accidentally or suicide or in drug abusers in opioid congeners Option: D . Death is due to respiratory failure in opioid poisonings.

questions.text: A patient was put on morphine for cancer pain due to carcinoma of the pancreas. His pain was relieved, and the patient took around 6 doses of morphine to get rid of the pain. He came to the emergency room with pinpoint pupil and respiratory depression. The best drug to reverse this is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Naloxone Naloxone is an opioid antagonist. It is used in the treatment of opioid toxicity. It counters and blocks the unwanted effects of opioid overdose.

Highyeild:

A case of morphine poisoning The specific antidote is Naloxone 0.4–0.8 mg i.v. Repeated every 2–3 min till respiration picks up Doesn’t depress respiration Depending on the response dose is repeated every 1–4 hours

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Methylnaltrexone is used to treat constipation caused by opioids. Option: B . Buprenorphine is used to treat opioid use disorder as a medication-assisted treatment. Option : D. Methadone is used primarily as substitution therapy for opioid dependence

questions.text: An opioid addict was bought to the psychiatry Department for de-addiction. The drug used for opioid dependence is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methadone The maintenance Drug for Dependence on Opioids Is Methadone. Methadone is long-acting, prevents withdrawal effects during opioid deaddiction, and also decreases the euphoric effect(kick) of opioids. Methadone is a potent mu-receptor agonist, and it suppresses the symptoms of opioids. Withdrawal Tolerance and physical dependence occur only at a slow rate with methadone compared to morphine. It is administered once daily, as it is long-acting. On abrupt discontinuation, it produces only mild withdrawal signs and symptoms. Hence methadone is used as substitution therapy for opioid dependence. A drug to prevent relapse of addiction is naltrexone. Naltrexone blocks all opioid receptors. When the patient tries to retake opioids, he will not get a euphoric effect as all the receptors are already blocked by naltrexone. So without getting a euphoric effect, the patient will not be retaking opioids.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist. It is used in the treatment of opioid toxicity. It counters and blocks the unwanted effects of opioid overdose. Option: B. Clonidine is a medicine for hypertension (high blood pressure). It lowers the blood pressure by relaxing the blood vessels. Lowering the blood pressure helps to prevent future strokes and heart attacks. Option: D. Naltrexone is used to treat opioid dependence and alcohol addiction. It works by blocking the euphoric feelings (highs) that Some people may experience after taking opiates and alcohol. This reduces the craving and helps you stay away from them.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with a painful stab wound. The junior resident gives pentazocine for the pain. Soon after administration, the patient experiences sweating, restlessness, and increased pain sensations. What is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient is probably tolerant to pentazocine.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient is a morphine addict

options.label: C
options.text: Pentazocine was used at the wrong dose.

options.label: D
options.text: Pentazocine doesn’t cross the blood-brain barrier

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient is a morphine addict
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The patient is a morphine addict

Highyeild:

Pentazocine is қ- an agonist (analgesia, dysphoria, nightmares and visual hallucinations) μ-antagonist and partial μ-agonist (less respiratory depression) So it should not be given in an opioid addict, because it blocks mu receptor and causes opioid withdrawal symptoms like sweating, restlessness, and an increase in pain sensations Injected in morphine-dependent subjects, it precipitates withdrawal. In pentazocine-dependent subjects, naloxone precipitates withdrawal, but at higher doses.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . The patient is probably tolerant to pentazocine. Option: C. Pentazocine was used at the wrong dose. Option: D. Pentazocine doesn’t cross the blood-brain barrier

questions.text: Tramadol is used in mild to moderate chronic and cancer pain. Which of the following statements is false about tramadol?

options.label: B
options.text: Supplied as a racemic mixture for use

options.label: D
options.text: Tramadol-induced respiratory depression cannot be reversed by naloxone

questions.correct_answer: D. Tramadol-induced respiratory depression cannot be reversed by naloxone
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tramadol-induced respiratory depression cannot be reversed by naloxone Reason- Tramadol-induced respiratory depression can be reversed by naloxone, but tramadol-induced analgesia is not entirely reversible by naloxone

Highyeild:

A synthetic codeine analog that is a weak MOR agonist Other mechanisms of its analgesic effect is produced by inhibition of uptake of norepinephrine and serotonin Effective for mild to moderate pain but less effective for severe and chronic pain Tramadol is as effective as meperidine in the treatment of labor pain and may cause less neonatal respiratory depression Tramadol induced respiratory depression can be reversed by naloxone but tramadol induced analgesia is not entirely reversible by naloxone Tramadol to be avoided with MAOIs and SSRIs

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Weak mu receptor agonist Option: B. Supplied as a racemic mixture for use Option: C. Inhibits serotonin and norepinephrine uptake

questions.text: What should be kept ready when we give narcotics to woman in term?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Naloxone Remember: Naloxone used for Neonatal resuscitation if opioid used during labour.

Highyeild:

FOR neonates, the initial dose is 10 μg/kg given intravenously, intramuscularly, or subcutaneously. Note: Naloxone is not used for Neonatal resuscitation if the mother is an opioid addict because of the precipitation of withdrawal in neonates. On the long-term addiction fetus is also dependent on opioids if you suddenly block the opioid receptor that will lead to opioid withdrawal.

questions.text: Ipratropium bromide is absolutely contraindicated in:
questions.explanation:

Urinary retention

Anti-cholinergic drugs have relaxant action on the ureter and urinary bladder, leading to urinary retention in older males with prostatic hypertrophy. questions.text: Among the following options, Conversion of codeine to morphine is catalyzed by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CYP2D6 Is an enzyme that in humans is encoded by the CYP2D6 gene. CYP2D6 is primarily expressed in the liver. It is also highly expressed in areas of the central nervous system, including the substantia nigra. CYP2D6, a member of the cytochrome P450 mixed-function oxidase system

Highyeild:

catalyzes the conversion of codeine to morphine. Well-characterized genetic polymorphisms in CYP2D6 lead to the inability to convert codeine to morphine this makes codeine ineffective as an analgesic for ~10% of the Caucasian population Other polymorphisms (e.g., the CYP2D6*2x2 genotype) can lead to ultra-rapid metabolism and thus increased sensitivity to codeine’s effects due to higher-than expected serum morphine levels in 4-5% of the US population and 16-28% of North Africans, Ethiopians, and Arabs

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. CYP3A4 is an important enzyme in the body, mainly found in the liver and in the intestine. It oxidizes small foreign organic molecules (xenobiotics), such as toxins or drugs, so that they can be removed from the body. Option: B. CYP1A1, CYP1A2/1B1 genes , is regulated by a heterodimeric transcription factor that consist of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor, a ligand activated transcription factor, and the aryl hydrocarbon receptor nuclear translocator. In the intestine, but not the liver, Option: D. CYP2C9 is a crucial cytochrome P450 enzyme, which plays a significant role in the metabolism, by oxidation, of both xenobiotic and endogenous compounds. CYP2C9 makes up about 18% of the cytochrome P450 protein in liver microsomes. The protein is mainly expressed in liver and duodenum.
